questions.text: A group of 6 college students with multiple sclerosis (MS) was evaluated for flares in a neurology clinic. The results are shown in the figure. Each row represents a patient. The gray bars represent the duration of the flare. The arrowheads indicate that the MS flare was already present before and/or persisted beyond the timeframe of the study. Based on the figure, which of the following is the most accurate statement about MS flares in this group of students?

choices.text: Incidence from April 1st to June 1st was 3
Incidence during the month of May was 2
Prevalence during the month of December was 50%
Incidence during the month of February was 3
Prevalence of the disease on May 15 was 4/6
Incidence proportion during this year was 3/6

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Only 2 patients (patients 3 and 5) developed MS flares between April and June. Patients 1 and 2 had already been diagnosed with an MS flare before the beginning of April (the incidence includes new cases only).

B) CORRECT:

Incidence is the number of new cases that develop during a specified period of time. Based on the figure, 2 new cases appeared in May (patient 3 and patient 5 developed an MS flare).

The incidence proportion (cumulative incidence, incidence proportion) is the proportion of the disease-free population that developed the disease during a specified time period. Incidence rate (person-time rate) is the number of new cases divided by the total person-time at risk (the time each person was at risk, totaled for all persons in the study). Incidence proportion and incidence rate are measures that represent the likelihood of developing the disease during a time period.

Prevalence is the proportion of a population that has a condition at a specified point in time (point prevalence) or during a specified time period (period prevalence).

C) INCORRECT:

Prevalence is the proportion of a population that has a condition at a specified point in time (point prevalence) or during a specified time period (period prevalence). During December, 2 of the 6 persons (∼ 33.3 %) had MS flares (patient 2 and 6).

D) INCORRECT:

Incidence is the number of new cases of a disease that develop during a specified period of time. Only 1 patient (patient 1) developed an MS flare in February. While patients 2 and 3 did have an MS flare in February, the onset of their symptoms began before February and therefore does not factor into the incidence for that month.

E) INCORRECT:

Prevalence is the proportion of a population that has a condition at a specified point in time (point prevalence) or during a specified time period (period prevalence). Of the six students evaluated, all but one (patient 4) had MS flares during this year at some point or for its entirety. The prevalence for the year is therefore 5/6.

F) INCORRECT:

Prevalence is the proportion of a population that has a condition at a specified point in time (point prevalence) or during a specified time period (period prevalence). On May 15th, 3 persons had MS flares (patients 2, 3, and 5) and the prevalence was 3/6.

G) INCORRECT:

The incidence proportion is the proportion of the disease-free population that developed the disease during a specified time period. In this case, the at-risk population for the year is 5 persons. Patient 2, who had a preexisting MS flare that continued for the entire year, is excluded, and patient 3, who had a preexisting MS flare but became disease-free (and hence at-risk) in March, is included. Since 4 of the 5 individuals at risk developed MS flares, the incidence proportion during the year was 4/5.
questions.hint: It is important to distinguish between new cases (e.g., new or recurring MS flares), preexisting cases, total population, and at-risk population when calculating measures of disease frequency.

questions.text:
Two separate investigators have conducted cohort studies to calculate the risk of lymphoma in rheumatoid arthritis patients taking anti-TNF alpha medications. They each followed patients with rheumatoid arthritis for a number of years and tracked the number of patients who were diagnosed with lymphoma. The results of the two studies are summarized in the table.



Number of patients
Mean followup period
Number of new cases of lymphoma




Study A
3000
10 years
30


Study B
300
30 years
9



Based on these results, which of the following statements about the risk of lymphoma is most accurate?

choices.text: The risk is higher in study B because the prevalence in study B is 9 cases per 300 patients
The risk is higher in study A because the incidence rate in study A is 30 cases per 10 person-years
The risks are equivalent because the prevalence in both studies is 39 cases per 3300 persons
The risks are equivalent because the incidence rate in both studies is 1 case per 1000 person-years
The risk is higher in study A because the prevalence in study A is 30 cases per 3000 patients
The risk is higher in study B because the cumulative incidence in study B is 9 cases per 300 patients

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prevalence generally does not allow conclusions to be drawn about risk. The exception is for diseases of very short duration (e.g., acute food poisoning), in which prevalence and incidence have approximately the same value.

B) INCORRECT:

The incidence rate of study A is not 30 cases per 10 person-years. It is crucial to consider the number of people observed (3000 patients) when measuring the incidence rate.

C) INCORRECT:

Prevalence generally does not allow conclusions to be drawn about risk. The exception is for diseases of very short duration (e.g., acute food poisoning), in which prevalence and incidence have approximately the same value.

D) CORRECT:

The incidence rate (IR) or person-time rate is a measure of risk that can be used when comparing groups with different followup periods. IR = (number of new cases)/(total person-time observation).

The total person-time observation for a study is the time each person was observed, totaled for all persons in the study. Alternatively, total person-time observation = (number of people observed) × (mean followup period).

The IR in study A is (30 cases)/(3000 persons × 10 years) = 1 case per 1000 person-years. The IR in study B is (9 cases)/(300 persons × 30 years) = 1 case per 1000 person-years. The IRs in both studies are the same and the risk is therefore equivalent.

Absolute risk (AR), which is the likelihood of an event occurring under specific conditions, is equivalent to cumulative incidence or incidence proportion (IP). IP = (number of new cases in a specific time period)/(number of people at risk). AR or IP is not a useful measure of risk when the followup periods are different.

E) INCORRECT:

Prevalence generally does not allow conclusions to be drawn about risk. The exception is for diseases of very short duration (e.g., acute food poisoning), in which prevalence and incidence have approximately the same value.

F) INCORRECT:

It is crucial to consider the differences in observation periods (10 years versus 30 years) and sample size (3000 versus 300 patients) when using measures of risk. The absolute risk (AR), which is equivalent to cumulative incidence or incidence proportion, is higher in study B (9 in 300 or 0.03) than in study A (30 in 3000 or 0.01) but these are not the appropriate measures to compare risk when studies have different followup periods.
questions.hint: An appropriately chosen measure of incidence indicates the risk of developing a condition.

questions.text: Many large clinics have noticed that the prevalence of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) has increased significantly over the past 20 years. An epidemiologist is working to identify possible reasons for this. After analyzing a series of nationwide health surveillance databases, the epidemiologist finds that the incidence of PBC has remained stable over the past 20 years. Which of the following is the most plausible explanation for the increased prevalence of PBC?

choices.text: Increased exposure to environmental risk factors for PBC
Improved quality of care for PBC
Increased availability of diagnostic testing for PBC
Increased average age of the population at risk for PBC
Increased awareness of PBC among clinicians

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An increase in exposure to environmental risk factors for PBC would likely result in an increased incidence and prevalence of PBC. In this case, however, incidence has remained stable for the past 20 years.

B) CORRECT:

In a stable population, the prevalence is approximated as the incidence multiplied by the average duration of the disease. An increased prevalence of disease with a stable incidence can be explained by an increase in the average duration of the disease. This occurs as a result of factors such as an improvement in the quality of care of patients with a disease, which decreases mortality from the disease and increases the duration for which people survive with the disease.
Image Description:

This image of a bathtub filling with water with a leak metaphorically represents the relationship of incidence, prevalence, and mortality (or recovery). Water entering the tub represents incident cases (new cases of disease). The proportion of the tub that is filled with water (prevalence of disease) is affected by both the amount of water entering the tub (incidence) and the amount of water leaving the tub (when people no longer have the disease because they died or because they recovered).

C) INCORRECT:

If diagnostic testing for PBC becomes more readily available, more people are diagnosed with the disease and, therefore, both incidence and prevalence would rise. In this case, incidence has remained stable for the past 20 years.

D) INCORRECT:

Because PBC is usually diagnosed between the ages of 35–65, an aging population would put more individuals at risk of developing PBC, and therefore lead to an increase in the number of new cases of PBC. This would, however, increase both the incidence and prevalence of the disease. In this case, the incidence of PBC has remained stable.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased awareness of PBC among clinicians would likely lead to a higher index of suspicion for PBC, increased testing, and, subsequently, an increase in the number of new diagnoses of PBC. In this case, however, the number of new diagnoses (i.e., incidence) has remained stable for the past 20 years.
questions.hint: The increased prevalence of PBC is unlikely to be attributable to increased incidence of PBC, given the stable number of new PBC cases over the past 20 years. More people are being documented as having PBC, while the number of new cases has remained the same.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the maternal and fetal consequences of a recent spike in benzodiazepine addiction in Ireland. She is particularly interested in whether benzodiazepine use contributes to the number of oral cleft deformities in newborns exposed to alprazolam, clonazepam, or lorazepam during the first trimester. The investigator uses statistical data from the local demographic institute to calculate the number of newly diagnosed cases of oral cleft deformities in Ireland over the past 5 years. Which of the following terms best describes the result of this calculation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mortality rate refers to the number of deaths within a group during a period of time. The investigator is interested in cases of disease, not death.

B) INCORRECT:

Prevalence includes all cases of a disease in a population, both new and preexisting, at a particular point in time. This investigator, however, is only interested in new cases of cleft deformities within the 5-year span.

C) INCORRECT:

Relative risk compares the risk of disease in one group (exposed to a risk factor) to the risk of disease in another group (without exposure to the risk factor). Although this investigator is interested in the rate of cleft deformities, she is not comparing two groups that differ by exposure to a risk factor.

D) CORRECT:

Cumulative incidence is the proportion of new cases of disease (in this case, cleft deformities) over a defined period of time (in this case, 5 years). It represents the likelihood of developing the disease during that time. It is calculated by dividing the number of new cases in a given time period by the population at risk in the same time interval.

E) INCORRECT:

Odds ratio is a statistical measure commonly used in case-control studies. Odds ratio compares the odds of exposure to a specific event or risk factor between a group with a disease and a group without the disease. This investigator is not comparing risk exposure between groups.

F) INCORRECT:

Attributable risk is the proportion of disease occurrence among exposed individuals attributable to that exposure. Here, however, the investigator is only considering the overall number of newly diagnosed cases of oral cleft deformities, irrespective of exposure status.
questions.hint: The investigator does not include preexisting cases of cleft deformities.

questions.text: A team of epidemiologists is investigating an outbreak of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) caused by Shiga toxin-producing E. coli O104:H4. In Europe, multiple episodes of illness were reported in May 2017 within a large extended family of 16 people who attended a reunion in late April where they all ate sprouts contaminated with E. coli. In the ensuing weeks, seven family members fell ill with HUS and were admitted to hospitals for treatment. A graph depicting the course of the disease in these individuals is shown. Each row represents a patient. Each gray bar represents the duration of the disease in the corresponding patient. Based on the graph, which of the following was the attack rate in the month of May among the individuals at risk?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Attack rate (cumulative incidence) is the proportion of individuals who developed an illness within a given period of time to the number who were exposed. According to the graph, six family members developed HUS in May, whereas all 16 were exposed. Although patient no. 5 developed HUS, their illness did not manifest until June. Therefore, the attack rate in May was 6/16.

B) INCORRECT:

This is the proportion of individuals who developed HUS in May (six) to the total number who developed the condition during the outbreak (seven). This figure does not represent the attack rate in May.

C) INCORRECT:

This is the proportion of family members who developed and recovered from HUS in May (five) to the 16 exposed family members. This figure does not represent the attack rate in May.

D) INCORRECT:

This is the proportion of family members who developed and recovered from HUS in May (five) to the total number who developed the condition during the entire observed time period (seven). This figure does not represent the attack rate in May.

E) INCORRECT:

Seven of the 16 exposed family members developed HUS over the entire observed time period. Although 7/16 is the overall attack rate for the outbreak, it is not the attack rate for the month of May alone.
questions.hint: The attack rate is the ratio of new cases to the number of individuals at risk.

questions.text: An investigator studying the epidemiology of breast cancer finds that prevalence of breast cancer has increased significantly in the United States since the 1980s. After analyzing a number of large epidemiological surveillance databases, the epidemiologist notices that the incidence of breast cancer has remained relatively stable over the past 30 years. Which of the following best explains these epidemiological trends?

choices.text: Increased awareness of breast cancer among clinicians
Increased average age of population at risk for breast cancer
Improved screening programs for breast cancer
Increased exposure to risk factors for breast cancer

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased awareness of breast cancer among clinicians would likely lead to a higher index of suspicion for breast cancer, increased testing, and, subsequently, an increase in the number of new diagnoses of breast cancer. In this case, however, the number of new diagnoses (i.e., incidence) has remained stable for the past 30 years.

B) INCORRECT:

Because the risk of breast cancer increased with age, an aging population would put more individuals at risk of developing breast cancer and therefore lead to an increase in the number of new cases. This would, however, increase both the incidence and prevalence of the disease. In this case, the incidence of breast cancer has remained stable.

C) INCORRECT:

If screening programs for breast cancer are improved, more people are diagnosed with the disease and, therefore, both incidence and prevalence would rise. In this case, incidence has remained stable for the past 30 years.

D) CORRECT:

In a stable population, the approximate prevalence is calculated as the incidence multiplied by the average duration of the disease. An increased prevalence of disease with a stable incidence can be explained by factors that result in increased survival and prolonged duration of the disease, such as improved treatment of patients with breast cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

An increase in exposure to risk factors for breast cancer would likely result in an increased incidence and prevalence of breast cancer. In this case, however, incidence has remained stable for the past 30 years.
questions.hint: The investigator found that more people are being documented as having breast cancer, while the number of new cases has remained the same.

questions.text: A clinical study of the entire population of 2500 individuals on an island finds that 500 have fasting hyperglycemia. Analysis of medical records of deceased individuals shows that the average age at onset of fasting hyperglycemia is 45 years, and the average overall life expectancy is 70 years. Assuming that the population and condition are in a steady state with no change in environmental risk factors, which of the following is the best estimate of the number of individuals who will newly develop fasting hyperglycemia over 1 year?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In populations with a steady state, incidence rates can be calculated from prevalence and the average duration of the disease. This answer is not the correct value.

B) INCORRECT:

In populations with a steady state, incidence rates can be calculated from prevalence and the average duration of the disease. This answer is not the correct value.

C) INCORRECT:

In populations with a steady state, incidence rates can be calculated from prevalence and the average duration of the disease. This answer is not the correct value.

D) INCORRECT:

In populations with a steady state, incidence rates can be calculated from prevalence and the average duration of the disease. This answer is not the correct value.

E) CORRECT:

In a steady state, the relationship between incidence rate (IR), prevalence (P), and the average duration of the condition (T) can be described mathematically as P/(1 - P) = IR x T. Because the average duration of fasting hyperglycemia is 25 years and its prevalence is 0.2, the incidence rate is 0.01 per year. Inserting the values for P and T into the formula results in 0.2/(1 - 0.2) = IR x 25; solving for IR results in 0.01. The best estimate of the number of individuals who will develop fasting hyperglycemia in one year is IR × population at risk or 0.01 × (2500 - 500) = 20.
Image Description:

This image of a bathtub filling with water with a leak metaphorically represents the relationship of incidence, prevalence, and mortality (or recovery). Water entering the tub represents incident cases (new cases of disease). The proportion of the tub that is filled with water (prevalence of disease) is affected by both the amount of water entering the tub (incidence) and the amount of water leaving the tub (when people no longer have the disease because they died or because they recovered).
questions.hint: Prevalence is calculated by dividing the number of individuals with fasting hyperglycemia by the total population: 500/2500 = 0.2. Average duration of the condition is calculated by subtracting the average age of onset from the average life expectancy: 70 - 45 = 25 years. There is a steady state when incidence is constant, prevalence is fairly constant, and the birth rate equals the death rate.

A journalist would like to report the yearly case fatality rate of the pneumonia pathogen responsible for most hospitalizations in these states. Based on the study results, which of the following responses by the investigator is most accurate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This value is the overall mortality rate for all patients of pneumonia that were admitted to the hospital: 137 deaths/1323 cases = 0.104 (or 10.4%). However, this journalist is asking about the mortality rate of pneumonia caused by one specific pathogen.

B) INCORRECT:

This value (69/137 ≈ 0.503, or 50.3%) is the proportional mortality rate of S. aureus pneumonia, i.e., the proportion of fatalities attributable to S. aureus. Although S. aureus is indeed the most common pathogen causing pneumonia that leads to hospital admission, this value does not represent the case fatality rate.

C) INCORRECT:

This value is the proportion of total cases caused by S. aureus, otherwise known as incidence: 460 cases/1323 total cases = 0.348 (or 34.8%). While this value correctly identifies S. aureus as the most common pathogen causing pneumonia that required hospital admission, the journalist is most interested in identifying the mortality rate of this infection, not the incidence.

D) CORRECT:

The case fatality rate for the most common organism causing pneumonia that requires hospitalization is 15.0%. There were 460 cases of pneumonia caused by S. aureus in the study cohort, of which 69 were fatal. The case fatality rate, therefore, is 69/460 = 0.15, or 15.0%.

E) INCORRECT:

This value is the case fatality rate from P. aeruginosa, 17 deaths/136 cases = 0.125 (or 12.5%). However, the journalist is interested in the case fatality rate of pneumonia caused by a different pathogen.
questions.hint: Of the given pathogens, S. aureus is responsible for most (34.8%) of the pneumonia cases requiring hospital admission in this cohort. The case fatality rate is the proportion of fatal cases of a specified disease within a reference period.

questions.text: A recent study examined trends in incidence and fatality of ischemic stroke in a representative sample of Scandinavian towns. The annual incidence proportion of ischemic stroke was calculated to be 60 per 2000 people. The 1-year case fatality rate for ischemic stroke was found to be 20%. The health department of a town in southern Sweden with a population of 20,000 is interested in knowing the 1-year mortality conferred by ischemic stroke. Based on the study's findings, which of the following estimates the annual mortality rate for ischemic stroke per 20,000?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This is the annual mortality rate per 2000 people. The question is asking for the annual mortality rate per 20,000 people.

B) CORRECT:

The annual mortality rate = annual incidence proportion × 1-year case fatality rate . The annual incidence proportion for ischemic stroke = 60/2000 = 0.03 (or 3%) in this study. A 1-year case fatality rate of 0.2 (or 20%) means that 12 of those 60 new cases each year die. The annual mortality rate = 0.03 × 0.2 = 0.006 (or 0.6%) , ie, 12 out of 2000 people die every year from ischemic stroke. In a population that is 10 times the size (20,000 people), 120 people would be expected to die every year from ischemic stroke (0.6% of 20,000).

C) INCORRECT:

The value of 400 (20% of 2000) is not the annual mortality rate per 20,000 people. In the study, 20% of the 60 people with an ischemic stroke died, not 20% of the entire sample population.

D) INCORRECT:

In the sample population, 60 out of 2000 individuals sustain an ischemic stroke and 20% of these 60 people die. Thus, an annual mortality rate of 60 per 20,000 would only be correct in the setting of a 1-year case fatality rate of 10% instead of the 20% found in the study.

E) INCORRECT:

This number represents the number of people in a population of 20,000 people who will suffer an ischemic stroke, not the annual mortality rate for ischemic stroke in 20,000 people . An annual mortality rate of 600 per 20,000 people would be obtained only if ischemic stroke was found to be fatal in 100% of cases. The 1-year case fatality rate in the sample population is only 20% so this number overestimates the number of deaths.
questions.hint: Mortality rate (crude death rate) for a disease (eg, ischemic stroke) is the frequency of deaths due to the disease in the total population within a specific time interval.

questions.text: An investigator is conducting a 6-month incidence study of a new viral respiratory disease in the population of a small town of 2500 residents. The virus seems to be infecting teenagers more often than adults. There is evidence that the virus provides long-term immunity after the infection has cleared. Prior to the investigation, 150 residents had developed the disease, 100 of whom were teenagers. During the 6 months of the study, another 400 residents were diagnosed with the disease, 350 of whom are teenagers. Which of the following is the incidence of the new disease for the given time period in this town?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This is the ratio of the number of teenagers who developed the disease in the 6-month study period (350) to the overall population at risk during the study (2350). The question asks about the incidence of the disease in the overall population rather than in a specific age group. If the question had asked for the 6-month incidence in teenagers, the total number of teenagers in the town (X) would be needed to calculate the number at risk of developing the disease during the study. The 6-month incidence for this age group would be 350/(X - 100).

B) INCORRECT:

This is the 6-month period prevalence of the disease. Prevalence does not account for the number of individuals at risk during a given period. 400/2500 = 16% is the ratio of new cases of disease during the 6-month study to the total number of residents regardless of their susceptibility to infection.

C) INCORRECT:

This is the period prevalence of the disease since its discovery. Prevalence does not account for the number of individuals at risk during a given period. 550/2500 = 22% is the ratio of new cases of the disease since its discovery to the total number of residents regardless of their susceptibility to infection.

D) CORRECT:

Cumulative incidence is calculated as the number of new cases of a disease divided by the number of people at risk in a given period. In this scenario, 400 residents develop the disease during the 6 months of the study. 2350 residents were at risk during the study (2500 residents - 150 residents who had already contracted the virus and have long-term immunity). Therefore, the 6-month cumulative incidence of the disease in this scenario is 400/2350 = 17.02%.

E) INCORRECT:

This is the ratio of the overall number of teenagers who developed the disease since the discovery of the disease (450) to the overall population (2500). The question asks about the 6-month incidence of the disease in the overall population rather than its period prevalence since discovery in a specific age group. If the question had asked for the prevalence of the disease in teenagers since its discovery, the total number of teenagers in the town (X) would be needed for the calculation. The period prevalence since the discovery of the disease for this age group would be 450/X.
questions.hint: Incidence is typically expressed either as a proportion (i.e., cumulative incidence) or as a rate (i.e., incidence rate). The data from this study can be used to calculate cumulative incidence, which is the proportion of the town's residents who newly developed the disease during the 6-month study period.

questions.text: Over a decade, the yearly number of newly diagnosed patients with a chronic condition has not changed, yet the total number of persons with this condition continues to increase. Which factor best explains this phenomenon?

choices.text: Longer disease duration due to improved therapy
Reduction in diagnostic accuracy across healthcare facilities

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Prevalence is determined by both the incidence and the duration of a disease. While the incidence remains constant, improved therapies can extend the lifespan of patients, increasing the duration of the disease. This is common in chronic conditions where better medical care reduces mortality rates, allowing more individuals to live longer with the condition. Consequently, the total number of individuals with the disease increases over time, reflecting the impact of enhanced healthcare on disease prevalence.

Key learning point: An increase in disease prevalence with constant incidence suggests improved quality of care, allowing patients to live longer with the disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Underreporting would lead to variability or a lower number of reported new cases, not a consistent annual incidence. The stable yearly number of new diagnoses suggests reliable data capture. The increasing total number of persons with the condition, despite stable incidence, indicates longer survival rather than underreporting.

C) INCORRECT:

Earlier progression to fatal outcomes would shorten disease duration, leading to a lower prevalence if incidence is constant. The increasing total number of persons with the condition suggests longer survival, not earlier fatal outcomes, which would decrease prevalence.

D) INCORRECT:

A reduction in diagnostic accuracy would affect the annual incidence, leading to changes in the number of new cases identified. The steady yearly number of newly diagnosed patients indicates consistent diagnostic criteria. The increasing prevalence is more likely due to improved survival and disease duration rather than diagnostic accuracy issues.

questions.text: You are a family medicine resident in an urban clinic serving a low‐income neighborhood. You note high rates of pediatric asthma hospitalizations among residents living in older housing with indoor mold. The local public health unit plans free inhalers and leaflets on trigger avoidance. However, mold persists due to structural issues and poverty. You want to target the problem at a population health level. Which one of the following is the best next step?

choices.text: Distribute portable HEPA filters to affected households.
Advocate for stricter national vehicle emission standards.
Partner with housing authorities to subsidize mold remediation.
Distribute educational leaflets on trigger avoidance at schools.
Provide subsidized inhalers through the public health unit.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Supplying portable HEPA filters reduces indoor exposure to allergens and particulates, offering individual-level relief but not rectifying hazardous living conditions or the underlying causes of mold growth in affected homes. This intervention is helpful but does not represent an overarching population health strategy aligned with equity or structural change.

B) INCORRECT:

National vehicle emission standards are an important environmental health policy, but these target outdoor air quality on a broad scale rather than the specific, high-priority indoor housing conditions driving asthma hospitalizations in this scenario. While relevant to long-term air quality, this solution does not address the immediate social and physical context for this population.

C) CORRECT:

Population health integrates socioeconomic and environmental determinants into health strategies. Partnering with housing authorities to subsidize mold remediation directly addresses substandard housing conditions, reducing asthma triggers at their source. This cross-sector collaboration leverages structural interventions to improve respiratory health across the community, rather than mitigating symptoms with inhalers or educational materials alone. Improving housing quality in low-income neighborhoods through cross-sector partnerships advances health equity and aligns with the Health in All Policies framework advocated by the Public Health Agency of Canada.

Key learning point: Population health interventions focus on targeting social and structural determinants to reduce health inequities, going beyond individual education or treatment by addressing root causes and fostering equity through systemic change.

D) INCORRECT:

Distributing educational leaflets increases knowledge so families may avoid some triggers, yet knowledge alone cannot mitigate risks like persistent indoor mold arising from poverty and substandard housing. Education is a public health intervention but does not modify root socioeconomic or environmental determinants at the community level.

E) INCORRECT:

Subsidized inhalers improve access to treatment, mitigating consequences of asthma but not addressing upstream socioeconomic or environmental determinants perpetuating high prevalence. This approach aligns with public health efforts focused on facilitating access to medical resources rather than on modifying major structural factors that drive health inequities.

choices.text: Incidence proportion during this year was 3/6.
Incidence during the month of February was 3.
Incidence during the month of May was 2.
Incidence from April 1st to June 1st was 3.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prevalence is the proportion of a population that has a condition at a specified point in time (point prevalence) or during a specified time period (period prevalence). Of the six students evaluated, all but one (patient 4) had MS flares during this year at some point or for its entirety. The prevalence for the year is therefore 5/6.

B) INCORRECT:

The incidence proportion is the proportion of the disease-free (at-risk) population that developed the disease during a specified period. In this case, the at-risk population for the year is 5 persons. Patient 2, who had a preexisting MS flare that continued for the entire year, is excluded and patient 3, who had a preexisting MS flare but became disease-free (and hence at-risk) in March is included. Since 4 of the 5 individuals at risk developed MS flares, the attack rate during the year was 4/5.

C) INCORRECT:

Incidence is the number of new cases of a disease that develop during a specified period of time. Only 1 patient (patient 1) developed an MS flare in February. While patients 2 and 3 did have an MS flare in February, the onset of their symptoms began before February and therefore does not factor into the incidence for that month.

D) CORRECT:

Incidence is the number of new cases that develop during a specified period of time. Based on the figure, 2 new cases appeared in May (patient 3 and patient 5 developed an MS flare).

The incidence proportion (cumulative incidence) is the proportion of the disease-free population that developed the disease during a specified time period. Incidence rate (person-time rate) is the number of new cases divided by the total person-time at risk (the time each person was at risk, totaled for all persons in the study). Prevalence is the proportion of a population that has a condition at a specified point in time (point prevalence) or during a specified time period (period prevalence).

Key learning point: Incidence measures the rate of new cases of disease in an at-risk population over a specified period of time.

E) INCORRECT:

Only 2 patients (patients 3 and 5) developed MS flares between April and June. Patients 1 and 2 had already been diagnosed with an MS flare before the beginning of April (the incidence includes new cases only).
questions.hint: It is important to distinguish between new cases (e.g., new or recurring MS flares), preexisting cases, total population, and at-risk population when calculating measures of disease frequency.

questions.text: Many large clinics have noticed that the prevalence of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) has increased significantly over the past 20 years. An epidemiologist is working to identify possible reasons for this. After analyzing a series of nationwide health surveillance databases, the epidemiologist finds that the incidence of PBC has remained stable over the past 20 years. Which of the following is the most plausible explanation for the increased prevalence of PBC?

choices.text: Improved quality of care for PBC.
Increased average age of the population at risk for PBC.
Increased availability of diagnostic testing for PBC.
Increased awareness of PBC among clinicians.
Increased exposure to environmental risk factors for PBC.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In a stable population, the prevalence is approximated as the incidence multiplied by the average duration of the disease. An increased prevalence of disease with a stable incidence can be explained by an increase in the average duration of the disease. This occurs as a result of factors such as an improvement in the quality of care of patients with a disease, which reduces mortality and allows people to survive longer with the disease.

Key learning point: Prevalence is approximately equal to incidence multiplied by the average disease duration in a stable population. Therefore, improved therapy that extends survival increases prevalence even if incidence remains unchanged.
Image Description:

This image of a bathtub filling with water with a leak metaphorically represents the relationship of incidence, prevalence, and mortality (or recovery). Water entering the tub represents incident cases (new cases of disease). The proportion of the tub that is filled with water (prevalence of disease) is affected by both the amount of water entering the tub (incidence) and the amount of water leaving the tub (when people no longer have the disease because they died or because they recovered).

B) INCORRECT:

Because PBC is usually diagnosed between the ages of 35–65, an aging population would put more individuals at risk of developing PBC, and therefore lead to an increase in the number of new cases of PBC. This would, however, increase both the incidence and prevalence of the disease. In this case, the incidence of PBC has remained stable.

C) INCORRECT:

If diagnostic testing for PBC becomes more readily available, more people are diagnosed with the disease and, therefore, both incidence and prevalence would rise. In this case, incidence has remained stable for the past 20 years.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased awareness of PBC among clinicians would likely lead to a higher index of suspicion for PBC, increased testing, and, subsequently, an increase in the number of new diagnoses of PBC. In this case, however, the number of new diagnoses (i.e., incidence) has remained stable for the past 20 years.

E) INCORRECT:

An increase in exposure to environmental risk factors for PBC would likely result in an increased incidence and prevalence of PBC. In this case, however, incidence has remained stable for the past 20 years.
questions.hint: The increased prevalence of PBC is unlikely to be attributable to the increased incidence of PBC, given the stable number of new PBC cases over the past 20 years. More people are being documented as having PBC, while the number of new cases has remained the same.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the maternal and fetal consequences of a recent spike in benzodiazepine addiction in Ireland. She is particularly interested in whether benzodiazepine use contributes to the number of oral cleft deformities in newborns exposed to alprazolam, clonazepam, or lorazepam during the first trimester. The investigator uses statistical data from the local demographic institute to calculate the number of newly diagnosed cases of oral cleft deformities in Ireland over the past 5 years. Which of the following terms best describes the result of this calculation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Relative risk compares the risk of disease in one group (exposed to a risk factor) to the risk of disease in another group (without exposure to the risk factor). Although this investigator is interested in the rate of cleft deformities, she is not comparing two groups that differ by exposure to a risk factor.

B) INCORRECT:

Prevalence includes all cases of a disease in a population, both new and preexisting, at a particular point in time. This investigator, however, is only interested in new cases of cleft deformities within the 5-year span.

C) INCORRECT:

Odds ratio is a statistical measure commonly used in case-control studies. Odds ratio compares the odds of exposure to a specific event or risk factor between a group with a disease and a group without the disease. This investigator is not comparing risk exposure between groups.

D) INCORRECT:

Attributable risk is the proportion of disease occurrence among exposed individuals attributable to that exposure. Here, however, the investigator is only considering the overall number of newly diagnosed cases of oral cleft deformities, irrespective of exposure status.

E) CORRECT:

Cumulative incidence is the proportion of new cases of disease (in this case, cleft deformities)in an at-risk population over a defined period of time (in this case, 5 years). It represents the likelihood of developing the disease during that time. It is calculated by dividing the number of new cases in a given time period by the population at risk in the same time interval.


Key learning point: Cumulative incidence is the proportion of at-risk individuals who develop new cases of a disease within a specified time period.
questions.hint: The investigator does not include preexisting cases of cleft deformities.

questions.text: A recent study examined trends in incidence and fatality of ischemic stroke in a representative sample of Scandinavian towns. The annual incidence proportion of ischemic stroke was calculated to be 60 per 2000 people. The 1-year case fatality rate for ischemic stroke was found to be 20%. The health department of a town in southern Sweden with a population of 20,000 is interested in knowing the 1-year mortality conferred by ischemic stroke. Based on the study's findings, which of the following estimates the annual mortality rate for ischemic stroke per 20,000?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In the sample population, 60 out of 2000 individuals sustain an ischemic stroke, and 20% of these 60 people die. Thus, an annual mortality rate of 60 per 20,000 would only be correct in the setting of a 1-year case fatality rate of 10% instead of the 20% found in the study.

B) INCORRECT:

This is the annual mortality rate per 2000 people. The question is asking for the annual mortality rate per 20,000 people.

C) INCORRECT:

The value of 400 (20% of 2000) is not the annual mortality rate per 20,000 people. In the study, 20% of the 60 people with an ischemic stroke die, not 20% of the entire sample population.

D) INCORRECT:

This number represents the number of people in a population of 20,000 people who will suffer an ischemic stroke, not the annual mortality rate for ischemic stroke in 20,000 people. An annual mortality rate of 600 per 20,000 people would be obtained only if ischemic stroke was found to be fatal in 100% of cases. The 1-year case fatality rate in the sample population is only 20% so this number overestimates the number of deaths.

E) CORRECT:

The annual mortality risk = annual incidence proportion × 1-year case fatality rate. The annual incidence proportion for ischemic stroke = 60/2000 = 0.03 (or 3%) in this study. A 1-year case fatality rate of 0.2 (or 20%) means that 12 of those 60 new cases each year die. The annual mortality rate = 0.03 × 0.2 = 0.006 (or 0.6%), i.e, 12 out of 2000 people die every year from ischemic stroke. In a population that is 10 times the size (20,000 people), the annual mortality rate is 120 per 20,000 people, meaning that in a population of 20,000, approximately 120 people would be expected to die from ischemic stroke each year (0.6% of 20,000).

Key learning point: The annual mortality rate for a condition is calculated as the number of deaths due to the condition in one year divided by the total population, often expressed per 1,000 or 100,000 people. It depends on both the incidence of the condition and the case fatality rate.
questions.hint: Mortality rate (crude death rate) for a disease (e.g., ischemic stroke) is the frequency of deaths due to the disease in the total population within a specific time interval.

questions.text: An investigator is conducting a 6-month incidence study of a new viral respiratory disease in the population of a small town of 2500 residents. The virus seems to be infecting teenagers more often than adults. There is evidence that the virus provides long-term immunity after the infection has cleared. Prior to the investigation, 150 residents had developed the disease, 100 of whom were teenagers. During the 6 months of the study, another 400 residents were diagnosed with the disease, 350 of whom were teenagers. Which of the following is the incidence of the new disease for the given time period in this town?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Cumulative incidence is calculated as the number of new cases of a disease divided by the number of people at risk in a given period. In this scenario, 400 residents develop the disease during the 6 months of the study. 2350 residents were at risk during the study (2500 residents - 150 residents who had already contracted the virus and have long-term immunity). Therefore, the 6-month cumulative incidence of the disease in this scenario is 400/2350 = 17.02%.

Key learning point: Cumulative incidence is determined by dividing the number of new cases during a specified period by the population at risk, excluding individuals who are already diseased or immune.

B) INCORRECT:

This is the period prevalence of the disease since its discovery. Prevalence does not account for the number of individuals at risk during a given period. 550/2500 = 22% is the ratio of new cases of the disease since its discovery to the total number of residents regardless of their susceptibility to infection.

C) INCORRECT:

This is the 6-month period prevalence of the disease. Prevalence does not account for the number of individuals at risk during a given period. 400/2500 = 16% is the ratio of new cases of disease during the 6-month study to the total number of residents regardless of their susceptibility to infection.

D) INCORRECT:

This is the ratio of the overall number of teenagers who developed the disease since the discovery of the disease (450) to the overall population (2500). The question asks about the 6-month incidence of the disease in the overall population rather than its period prevalence since discovery in a specific age group. If the question had asked for the prevalence of the disease in teenagers since its discovery, the total number of teenagers in the town (X) would be needed for the calculation. The period prevalence since the discovery of the disease for this age group would be 450/X.

E) INCORRECT:

This is the ratio of the number of teenagers who developed the disease in the 6-month study period (350) to the overall population at risk during the study (2350). The question asks about the incidence of the disease in the overall population rather than in a specific age group. If the question had asked for the 6-month incidence in teenagers, the total number of teenagers in the town (X) would be needed to calculate the number at risk of developing the disease during the study.
questions.hint: Incidence is typically expressed either as a proportion (i.e., cumulative incidence) or as a rate (i.e., incidence rate). The data from this study can be used to calculate cumulative incidence, which is the proportion of the town's at-risk residents who developed the disease during the 6-month study period.

questions.text: An investigator studying the epidemiology of breast cancer finds that prevalence of breast cancer has increased significantly in Canada since the 1980s. After analyzing a number of large epidemiological surveillance databases, the investigator notices that the incidence of breast cancer has remained relatively stable over the past 30 years. Which of the following best explains these epidemiological trends?

choices.text: Increased awareness of breast cancer among clinicians.
Increased average age of population at risk for breast cancer.
Increased exposure to risk factors for breast cancer.
Improved screening programs for breast cancer.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In a stable population, the approximate prevalence is calculated as the incidence multiplied by the average duration of the disease. An increased prevalence of disease with a stable incidence can be explained by factors that result in increased survival and prolonged duration of the disease, such as improved treatment of patients with breast cancer.

Key learning point: An increasing prevalence with stable incidence indicates a longer disease duration, often due to improved therapies that prolong survival.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased awareness of breast cancer among clinicians would likely lead to a higher index of suspicion for breast cancer, increased testing, and, subsequently, an increase in the number of new diagnoses of breast cancer. In this case, however, the number of new diagnoses (i.e., incidence) has remained stable for the past 30 years.

C) INCORRECT:

Because the risk of breast cancer increased with age, an aging population would put more individuals at risk of developing breast cancer and therefore lead to an increase in the number of new cases. This would, however, increase both the incidence and prevalence of the disease. In this case, the incidence of breast cancer has remained stable.

D) INCORRECT:

An increase in exposure to risk factors for breast cancer would likely result in an increased incidence and prevalence of breast cancer. In this case, however, incidence has remained stable for the past 30 years.

E) INCORRECT:

If screening programs for breast cancer are improved, more people are diagnosed with the disease and, therefore, both incidence and prevalence would rise. In this case, incidence has remained stable for the past 30 years.
questions.hint: The investigator found that more people are being documented as having breast cancer, while the number of new cases has remained the same.

questions.text: A 28-year-old health care worker presents to the ED with fever, diaphoresis, and headache after returning from working in a refugee camp in West Africa. She reports that over the past month, there has been a steady occurrence of similar cases among camp residents, with approximately 3–5 new cases weekly. The condition has persisted at this rate for the past 6 months since the camp was established. Local health officials recognize this illness pattern as typical for this geographic region. What classification best describes this disease pattern?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Epidemic diseases are characterized by rapid increases in disease occurrence within a limited time period and geographic area. This patient describes a constant rate rather than a rapid increase, and the 6-month duration suggests a sustained pattern rather than the limited timeframe typical of epidemics.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient describes an endemic disease pattern. Endemic diseases affect individuals at a relatively constant rate within a specific population in a given region. The steady occurrence of 3–5 cases weekly over 6 months in a specific region with local health officials recognizing this as typical for the area indicates endemic disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Pandemic diseases affect wide geographic areas such as multiple countries or continents. This patient describes a disease pattern that is limited to a specific refugee camp and region.

D) INCORRECT:

Sporadic diseases occur irregularly and infrequently in a population; this patient describes a steady pattern of 3–5 cases weekly over 6 months.

E) INCORRECT:

An outbreak is a sudden increase in disease occurrence above expected levels in a specific population or area. The steady, expected pattern over 6 months described by this patient does not represent the sudden increase characteristic of an outbreak.

questions.text: An emergency medicine physician wants to examine the burden of disease from COVID on his local community. What statistic would best estimate the disease burden?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Incidence measures only the number of new cases of disease in a population over a specific time period, but does not account for the duration, severity, or disability associated with the disease. This metric fails to capture the full impact of disease on a population, which includes factors such as premature death, years lived with disability, and overall quality of life effects.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) represent the most comprehensive measure of disease burden as they quantify years of life lost due to disease, disability, and premature death. This metric captures both mortality and morbidity impacts by combining years of life lost to premature death with years lived with disability, providing a complete assessment of the total health impact of COVID-19 on the community that accounts for both fatal and non-fatal health outcomes.

C) INCORRECT:

Prevalence measures the proportion of people with disease at a specific point in time, indicating how common the condition is in the population. However, this metric does not capture the severity, duration, disability, or mortality impact of the disease, which are essential components for assessing the overall burden of illness on a community.

D) INCORRECT:

Mortality rate measures only the frequency of deaths in a population during a specific time period, but fails to account for the non-fatal impacts of disease such as disability, reduced quality of life, and years lived with illness. This measure provides an incomplete assessment of disease burden as it excludes the substantial morbidity effects that contribute to the overall health impact on a community.

E) INCORRECT:

Case fatality rate measures only the percentage of diagnosed cases that result in death, providing information about disease severity among those infected but not the overall population impact. This metric fails to capture the broader disease burden including non-fatal health outcomes, disability effects, and the total community-wide impact of illness.

questions.text: An emergency medicine physician wants to initiate a public health campaign targeting the leading cause of death in adolescents and young adults. What is the leading cause of death for individuals aged 15–34 in the US?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cancer is the leading cause of death in adults aged 45–65 years, but is not a leading cause of death in individuals aged 15–34 years .

B) INCORRECT:

Suicide is the second leading cause of death among individuals aged 15–34 years in the US.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Unintentional injuries represent the leading cause of death among individuals aged 15–34 years in the US.

D) INCORRECT:

Homicide is the third leading cause of death among individuals aged 15–34 years in the US.

E) INCORRECT:

Heart disease is the leading cause of death in adults > 65 years old, but is not a leading cause of death in individuals aged 15–34 years.

questions.text: An emergency physician is serving as the hospital's liaison for pandemic response coordination. During a monthly review with public health officials, surveillance data shows that while the weekly incidence rate of confirmed cases presenting to the emergency department has remained stable at 15 cases per 100,000 population, the overall prevalence of active cases in the community has decreased from 120 to 85 cases per 100,000 population over the past month. What is the most likely explanation for this epidemiological pattern?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- The relationship between prevalence, incidence, and disease duration is expressed as prevalence = incidence × average duration of disease. When incidence remains stable but prevalence decreases, this indicates that the average duration of illness has shortened, likely due to more effective treatments or earlier interventions reducing recovery time.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased population screening would detect more cases, typically increasing both incidence and prevalence rather than decreasing prevalence and keeping incidence stable.

C) INCORRECT:

Improved diagnostic testing accuracy would typically increase both incidence and prevalence rather than decrease prevalence by detecting more cases that were previously missed.

D) INCORRECT:

Reduced disease transmission rates would decrease the incidence rate by preventing new cases from occurring, which is not consistent with the stable incidence pattern observed.

E) INCORRECT:

Enhanced contact tracing would reduce incidence rather than keeping it stable by identifying and isolating cases earlier.

questions.text: A graduate student in public health is conducting a study on population health and is comparing different demographic models. He is particularly interested in investigating health care interventions in societies with the demographic distribution shown. Which of the following measures is most likely to ensure a healthy demographic transition in this population?

choices.text: Invest in workplace health and safety measures
Invest in type II diabetes research programs
Invest in prostate cancer screening programs

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Investing in workplace health and safety measures would have an impact on populations in which a large proportion of individuals are employed, i.e., those with a significant middle-aged population. However, this population is predominantly youthful, with a large proportion of individuals under the age of 20. Investing in workplace health and safety measures would, therefore, impact only a small proportion of the population.

B) CORRECT:

Investing in interventions for children such as childhood immunization programs is most likely to ensure a healthy demographic transition in a youthful population. The goal of healthy demographic transitions is to lower death rates, lower birth rates, and ensure a healthy aging population. In the given population, the majority of individuals are young. Consequently, interventions that reduce child mortality and reproduction (e.g., by improving access to contraceptives) are likely to have a positive impact on the demographic distribution.
Image Description:

This population pyramid has a wide base, which indicates a greater proportion of individuals in younger age categories than in older age categories.

This distribution reflects a population with high birth rates and low life expectancy, which indicates rapid population growth.

C) INCORRECT:

Investing in type II diabetes research would be beneficial in populations with a significant middle-aged and elderly population. However, this population is predominantly youthful, with the majority of individuals under the age of 20. In individuals under the age of 20, type II diabetes is rare. Investing in diabetes research would therefore not benefit a large proportion of the population.
Image Description:

This population pyramid has a narrowed base, indicating a smaller proportion of individuals in the younger age categories relative to those in older categories.

This distribution reflects a population with a low birth rate and high life expectancy, which indicates zero population growth or population decline.

D) INCORRECT:

Investing in prostate cancer screening programs might lower the death rate of elderly men and would therefore be beneficial in communities with a significant elderly population. However, this population is predominantly youthful, with the majority of individuals under the age of 20. Investing in prostate cancer screening programs would therefore not benefit a large proportion of the population.
Image Description:

This population pyramid has a narrowed base, indicating a smaller proportion of individuals in the younger age categories relative to those in older categories.

This distribution reflects a population with a low birth rate and high life expectancy, which indicates zero population growth or population decline.

E) INCORRECT:

Investing in long-term care facilities would be beneficial in communities with a significant elderly population. However, this population is predominantly youthful, with the majority of individuals under the age of 20. Investing in long-term care facilities would therefore not benefit a large proportion of the population.
Image Description:

This population pyramid has a narrowed base, indicating a smaller proportion of individuals in the younger age categories relative to those in older categories.

This distribution reflects a population with a low birth rate and high life expectancy, which indicates zero population growth or population decline.
questions.hint: The illustration shows an expansive pyramid, reflecting a youthful population with high birth rates and low life expectancy.
